FacilityName: City Sugar Land South Wastewater Treatment Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ECO Resources, Inc. (ECO) operates and maintains the City of Sugar Land South Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP), located along Oil Field Road, south of Commonwealth Boulevard, in Fort Bend County, Texas.  The 7.5-mgd facility treats domestic sewage and waste sludge, and is situated amongst residential properties.  Treated effluent from the facility is chlorinated to kill pathogenic organisms using chlorine gas and dechlorinated with sulfur dioxide to remove residual chlorine from the effluent prior to its release to the receiving stream.  Chlorine and sulfur dioxide are hazardous substances, as defined by 40 CFR 68 and 29 CFR 1910.119, and would pose a threat to human health and safety and to environmental receptors if released.  The presence these two chemicals onsite mandates that a Risk Management Plan (RMP) be developed in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.119 to provide guidance and procedures for preventing or minimizing the consequences of the accidental hazardous release of gaseous chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide.  The existing RMP for the South WWTP was developed in June of 1999.  



For the RMP to be effective, the plant operator must become familiar with its contents through routine training and review of the prescribed procedures.  An update of the RMP must be performed every five years to review established procedures and practices outlined in the existing document and to check and revise each of the nine sections within the RMP*Submit program for accuracy.  



In the event of a toxic release, worst-case and alternate scenarios were examined as part of the RMP*Submit Program.  The scenarios utilized the EPA Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants to model the distance to the toxic end point.  The worst-case scenario, a gas release, for both chlorine and sulfur dioxide assumes an urban setting with a distance of 1.3 miles to the toxic end point, which would impact 6700 people.  The alternate scenario for chlorine and sulfur dioxide,

a pipe leak, also assumes an urban setting and has a distance of 0.2 miles to the toxic end point, and affects no people.  In addition, a process safety hazard analysis was conducted using the program?s what-if methodology.  The consequences of both the worst-case and alternate scenarios for several what-if situations were analyzed and ways to prevent or minimize these consequences are provided in the original RMP.  



The following paragraphs detail the information, processes, and procedures described in the existing RMP that are currently in place at the South WWTP and were recently reviewed during the RMP Audit in September of 2003.



Section 3, Process Safety Information, provides information regarding the physical properties and characteristics of chlorine and sulfur dioxide, as well as the process chemistry of the gases, chlorine and sulfur dioxide equipment information and Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) for each chemical.



Section 4, Process Hazard Analysis, describes the process hazard analysis performed for the City of Sugar Land South WWTP.  An initial process hazard analysis was performed by ECO, which identified and evaluated all actual, potential and probable hazardous situations that might occur at the plant.  Based on the facility?s history, no events were identified that could be considered an incident, i.e., which had a likely potential for causing catastrophic consequences in the workplace.  



Section 5, Operating Procedures, provides information regarding the handling and storage of chlorine and sulfur dioxide, procedures outlining how to change and repair chlorine and sulfur dioxide cylinders, safety protection measures to be follow when dealing with the two chemicals, and emergency situations which could result when dealing with the two gases and the appropriate procedures to follow should these events occur.



Section 6, Training, mandates that ECO provide training for individuals operating chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide processes, a

nd that refresher training be held for plant personnel on an annual basis.  



Section 7, Contractors, states that all ECO employees shall inform outside contractors of (1) the known potential toxic release hazards of chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide, and (2) how they should respond should an emergency occur while they are working at the Sugar Land South WWTP.   ECO employees are responsible for presenting this information to all outside contractors in written form as outlined in the original RMP.  This Contract Information Packet shall include Section 3 - Process Safety Information, Section 10 - Hot Work, and Section 13 - Emergency Planning and Response from the original RMP.  



Section 9, Mechanical Integrity, outlines the procedures to be followed at the Sugar Land South WWTP regarding preventive maintenance, inspection, testing, training, and quality assurance of chlorine and sulfur dioxide equipment.  



Section 10, Hot Work Permit, states that due to the type of process chemicals (chlorine and sulfur dioxide) being utilized at the Sugar Land South WWTP, hot work, such as soldering, welding or brazing, shall not be performed on or near these processes, or at any other location on site.  



Section 11, Management of Change, states that in the event of a modification to the facility, which affects the technology, chemicals, equipment, and procedures being utilized, the operator shall comply with certain procedures prior to the change being implemented, including the completion of the Management of Change Form.  



Section 12, Incident Investigation, provides an incident investigation form designed to determine the cause of an accident involving chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide and to put into action procedures to prevent an accident from occurring repeatedly.



All available records indicate that no spills or leaks that involved a reportable quantity of a toxic chemical have occurred at the Sugar Land South WWTP since the adoption of the current RMP.  Section

13, Emergency Planning and Response, of the RMP document outlines the procedures to be followed by all facility personnel in the event of an accidental release of gaseous chlorine or sulfur dioxide.  Specifically, Section 13 includes an Emergency Response Plan (ERP), which addresses the requirements of 40 CFR 68 pertaining to notification, medical treatment, response procedures, planning, use and maintenance of emergency equipment, employee safety training, and emergency response evaluation.
